>> So this video uh is probably how you

Uh
today we're going to learn about TV2 and

head of technology and production at

I would like to briefly share a bit of
uh about our vision for uh this project.
So welcome.
Before we dive into the project, let me
briefly introduce uh TB2 FUN. We are a
publicly funded regional media house
created to ensure strong local
journalism by the people of Aunan for
the people of Funan in Denmark. We are
around 130 colleagues based in the
largest city in this region.
Traditionally, we have been a broadcast
focused newsroom producing four daily TV
news shows that that reaches around 40
to 50 viewers on average. But today,
just like any other media organization,
our work has expanded far beyond
television. We publish news and stories
around the clock on our website tb2.dk
and on platforms like Facebook,
Instagram, Tik Tok, and YouTube. Because
for us, it's simple. We need to be where
the people of Funan are. Our existence
depends on people choosing to engage
with our journalism.
>> I just need to add one little thing in
there. Uh now granted TV is a local
Danish podcaster in Denmark is not the
most populous country on the planet.
However, they do have a bit more than 30
to 40 viewers. Uh so we're missing a

viewers uh are are viewing their
content.
Previously here at TB2, we had a
graphics platform that only produced
visuals for our television broadcasts.
It did the job well, but we quickly
realized the limitations. We couldn't
really see the potential for developing
platform neutral graphics. And on top of
that, it was difficult to find
developers and designers locally who had
strong knowledge of the product. So we
set ourselves a new ambition to build a
graphics platform that was independent
of our journalistic [snorts]
platforms but still able to support and
strengthen [music]
everything we published. For us,
flexibility and scalability were key.
The new system needed to deliver to all
of TV2's journalistic and digital
platforms without adding extra costs or
requiring more resources. And just as
importantly, it had to integrate
smoothly with our existing systems and
be compatible with our other production
tools. That way, we could create a
smarter and more efficient workflow
across teams and areas of expertise.
How did the idea actually come about?
Well, back in December 2019, Rasmos
Fulgar, our head director, attended the
Unreal Academy in London. That
experience opened up a whole new world.
After seeing what Unreal Engine was
capable of, he began to wonder, how
could we possibly take advantage of all
those possibilities within our world of
journalistic video? That was the
starting point. The big question became,
how can we integrate gaming technology
into an automated broadcast environment?
From there, the idea grew to build a
graphics platform powered by Unreal
Engine. One that would allow us to use
graphics seamlessly across both
television and digital platforms and
importantly without requiring more
resources than we already had. But how
do we do that in the best possible way?
At the same time, the everyday workflow
for users had to remain flexible and
simple based on templates and
automation. As you know by now, we are a
relatively small media house. We have to
be very precise in how we prioritize our
resources. It was clear to us from the
very beginning that we could not take on
this major task alone. integrating an
Unreal Enginebased graphics platform
into our existing newsroom system saga
running on Mosart automation. That left
us with two major tasks. First to create
a platform built on Unreal Engine and
second to integrate that platform into
our systems in such a way that our users
would gain a powerful tool that also
worked in everyday production. So we
needed strong partners with knowledge of
Unreal Engine graphics platform
development and integration with
newsroom systems and that's why we
teamed up with Milk and Honey and
Irisos. Together we agreed to start with
the foundation a temple a templatebased
automated graphic system for broadcast
use.
Good. All right. So now we kind of know

and that has continuous development in

And another thing is, of course, being
in Unreal Engine, there's more
possibility for the designer to actually
be in the suite that's going to play out
the graphics. And that has traditionally
been an issue in doing broadcast news
that the designers actually want to see
the final output when they are when they
are building their graphics. They don't
want to deliver something very very
clean, very very good-looking into an
integrator that sort of does it 75%.
they want the full uh implementation.
So to iterate on this the what we did
usually was people were working in
cinema or Adobe After Effects and
delivering renders of this is how it's
going to look and then it should be
integrated into a real-time playout

But for this we are moving more and more

additional software packages as cinema
as um Adobe After Effects and Blender as
well to act as supporting packages that
are then delivering into Unreal Engine
and then the final composite is done in
there where it's also played out. So
what you see is what you get when you
have when you're working with the
graphics.
And that also there's lots of advantages
of this. For example, when we want to
change something, we do it directly in

with with Blast, we had changes that
were that were on air like 20 seconds
after they were they were actually done
on several engines. So, but the solution

which is a a much much more easy way to
handle project versioning and is
essentially a a a simple version control
system that can push to push to all of
the engines uh immediately
and and creative hub talks with studio
which is the heart of the system
essentially and that studio is serving

they can fill out that data. They can

playing out the whole show. It is of

Yeah. So, so the key components here is
of course I resource handling the
communication and then all the graphics
are built in UMG right now. Um, and that
that was that was chosen when we started
this project because it is very
lightweight and it's fast and it's it's

If we make a cool animation, it's easy
to or a cool element, we can easily
place that on other graphics and reuse
it with the with data as well. And and
the way I built it was that I was I was
very focused on having a clean system
that can run all the time so that memory
doesn't clutter up or it starts getting
slower as you do more and more. So
everything is being spawned as dynamic
actors where the actor can have a task
that could be show a graphic or it could
be update some global variables that all
the graphics are talking into or it
could be clear an output or it could be
do do all sorts of tasks but whenever
that actor isn't done with its task it
destroys itself and cleans up nicely so
we have a clean slate to work on all the
time. Um and then of course one of the
big things in broadcast graphics is
transition logic which is essentially
the idea of graphics acting differently
depending on what is already on. And uh
and for that we did the transition logic
inside blueprints and we also utilized
the inbuilt transition logic with the
resource that comes with the resource.
But for this it was a quite complex

because this automation system it can it

this graphic has to go in and out at the

in between which an operator would never
do. They would follow the flow of of the
broadcast. So for making this work with
the automation system, it had to be

and and making sure that all these edge
